title: Modeling Tabular Running Track with Slope Field

content.question: NO CALCULATOR IS ALLOWED FOR THIS QUESTION.Show all of your work, even though the question may not explicitly remind you to do so. Clearly label any functions, graphs, tables, or other objects that you use. Justifications require that you give mathematical reasons, and that you verify the needed conditions under which relevant theorems, properties, definitions, or tests are applied. Your work will be scored on the correctness and completeness of your methods as well as your answers. Answers without supporting work will usually not receive credit.Unless otherwise specified, answers (numeric or algebraic) need not be simplified. If your answer is given as a decimal approximation, it should be correct to three places after the decimal point.Unless otherwise specified, the domain of a function <math alttext="f" display="inline" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mstyle><mrow><mi>f</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> is assumed to be the set of all real numbers <math alttext="x" display="inline" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mstyle><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> for which <math alttext="f of x" display="inline" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mstyle><mrow><mi>f</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> is a real number. <math alttext="The figure presents a two row table with 3 columns of data. The heading for row 1 is “t, in minutes.” The heading for row 2 is “R of t, in meters per minute.” The data in the table are as follows. Column 1. t is 0. R of t is 40. Column 2. t is 5. R of t is 200. Column 3. t is 20. R of t is 160. " display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtable align="center" columnlines="solid" equalrows="true" frame="solid" rowlines="solid" width="auto"><mtr><mtd><mrow><mtable><mtr><mtd><mi>t</mi></mtd></mtr><mtr><mtd><mrow><mtext>(minutes)</mtext></mrow></mtd></mtr></mtable></mrow><mo>⁢</mo></mtd><mtd><mn>0</mn></mtd><mtd><mn>5</mn></mtd><mtd><mn>20</mn></mtd></mtr><mtr><mtd><mrow><mtable><mtr><mtd><mrow><mi>R</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mtd></mtr><mtr><mtd><mrow><mtext>(meters per minute)</mtext></mrow></mtd></mtr></mtable></mrow></mtd><mtd><mn>40</mn></mtd><mtd><mn>200</mn></mtd><mtd><mn>160</mn></mtd></mtr></mtable></mrow></mstyle></math> A student on the school track and field team is running on the track. For time <math alttext="t" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>t</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> minutes, <math alttext="0 is less than or equal to t, is less than or equal to 20" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mrow><mn>0</mn><mo>≤</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>≤</mo><mn>20</mn></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math>, the rate at which the student runs, in meters per minute, is modeled by a twice-differentiable function, <math alttext="R of t" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>R</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math>. Values of <math alttext="R of t" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>R</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> at various times <math alttext="t" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>t</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> are shown in the table above. (a) Using correct units, approximate <math alttext="R prime of 5" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msup><mrow><mi>R</mi></mrow><mrow><mo>′</mo></mrow></msup><mrow><mo>(</mo><mn>5</mn><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> using the average rate of change of <math alttext="R" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>R</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> over the interval <math alttext="0 is less than or equal to t, is less than or equal to 20" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mrow><mn>0</mn><mo>≤</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>≤</mo><mn>20</mn></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math>.

frqParts.text: NO CALCULATOR IS ALLOWED FOR THIS QUESTION.Show all of your work, even though the question may not explicitly remind you to do so. Clearly label any functions, graphs, tables, or other objects that you use. Justifications require that you give mathematical reasons, and that you verify the needed conditions under which relevant theorems, properties, definitions, or tests are applied. Your work will be scored on the correctness and completeness of your methods as well as your answers. Answers without supporting work will usually not receive credit.Unless otherwise specified, answers (numeric or algebraic) need not be simplified. If your answer is given as a decimal approximation, it should be correct to three places after the decimal point.Unless otherwise specified, the domain of a function <math alttext="f" display="inline" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mstyle><mrow><mi>f</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> is assumed to be the set of all real numbers <math alttext="x" display="inline" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mstyle><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> for which <math alttext="f of x" display="inline" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mstyle><mrow><mi>f</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> is a real number. <math alttext="The figure presents a two row table with 3 columns of data. The heading for row 1 is “t, in minutes.” The heading for row 2 is “R of t, in meters per minute.” The data in the table are as follows. Column 1. t is 0. R of t is 40. Column 2. t is 5. R of t is 200. Column 3. t is 20. R of t is 160. " display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtable align="center" columnlines="solid" equalrows="true" frame="solid" rowlines="solid" width="auto"><mtr><mtd><mrow><mtable><mtr><mtd><mi>t</mi></mtd></mtr><mtr><mtd><mrow><mtext>(minutes)</mtext></mrow></mtd></mtr></mtable></mrow><mo>⁢</mo></mtd><mtd><mn>0</mn></mtd><mtd><mn>5</mn></mtd><mtd><mn>20</mn></mtd></mtr><mtr><mtd><mrow><mtable><mtr><mtd><mrow><mi>R</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mtd></mtr><mtr><mtd><mrow><mtext>(meters per minute)</mtext></mrow></mtd></mtr></mtable></mrow></mtd><mtd><mn>40</mn></mtd><mtd><mn>200</mn></mtd><mtd><mn>160</mn></mtd></mtr></mtable></mrow></mstyle></math> A student on the school track and field team is running on the track. For time <math alttext="t" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>t</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> minutes, <math alttext="0 is less than or equal to t, is less than or equal to 20" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mrow><mn>0</mn><mo>≤</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>≤</mo><mn>20</mn></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math>, the rate at which the student runs, in meters per minute, is modeled by a twice-differentiable function, <math alttext="R of t" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>R</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math>. Values of <math alttext="R of t" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>R</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> at various times <math alttext="t" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>t</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> are shown in the table above. (a) Using correct units, approximate <math alttext="R prime of 5" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msup><mrow><mi>R</mi></mrow><mrow><mo>′</mo></mrow></msup><mrow><mo>(</mo><mn>5</mn><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> using the average rate of change of <math alttext="R" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>R</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> over the interval <math alttext="0 is less than or equal to t, is less than or equal to 20" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mrow><mn>0</mn><mo>≤</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>≤</mo><mn>20</mn></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math>.

(b) Explain the meaning of <math alttext="R prime of 5" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msup><mrow><mi>R</mi></mrow><mrow><mo>′</mo></mrow></msup><mrow><mo>(</mo><mn>5</mn><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> in the context of the problem.

(c) The function <math alttext="D of t" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>D</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> models the number of meters run by the student at time <math alttext="t" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>t</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> minutes, where <math alttext="D, prime of t, equals, R of t" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msup><mrow><mi>D</mi></mrow><mrow><mo>′</mo></mrow></msup><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow><mo>=</mo><mi>R</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math>. It is known that <math alttext="D of 5 equals 800" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>D</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mn>5</mn><mo>)</mo></mrow><mo>=</mo><mn>800</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>. Write an equation for the line tangent to the graph of <math alttext="y equals D of t" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>y</mi><mo>=</mo><mi>D</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> at <math alttext="t equals 5" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>t</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>5</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>.

(d) Find the value of <math alttext="the integral from 0 to 5, of, R prime of, open parenthesis, 4, t, close parenthesis, d t" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mrow><msubsup><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mrow><mo>∫</mo></mrow></mstyle><mrow><mn>0</mn></mrow><mrow><mn>5</mn></mrow></msubsup><mrow><msup><mrow><mi>R</mi></mrow><mrow><mo>′</mo></mrow></msup><mrow><mo>(</mo><mn>4</mn><mi>t</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow><mo>ⅆ</mo><mrow><mi>t</mi></mrow></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math>. Show the calculations that lead to your answer.

(e) Use a trapezoidal sum with the two subintervals indicated by the table to approximate <math alttext="the integral from 0 to 20, of, R of t, d t" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mrow><msubsup><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mrow><mo>∫</mo></mrow></mstyle><mrow><mn>0</mn></mrow><mrow><mn>20</mn></mrow></msubsup><mrow><mi>R</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow><mo>ⅆ</mo><mrow><mi>t</mi></mrow></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math>. Show the calculations that lead to your answer.

(f) The student and a friend team up to run on the school track for a fundraiser for <math alttext="20" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>20</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> minutes. For <math alttext="0 less than or equal to t, less than or equal to 20" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mrow><mn>0</mn><mo>≤</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>≤</mo><mn>20</mn></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math>, the total number of laps run by the student is modeled by <math alttext="M of t" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>M</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> and the total number of laps run by the friend is modeled by <math alttext="L of t" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>L</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math>. Both <math alttext="M" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>M</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> and <math alttext="L" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>L</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> are differentiable functions of <math alttext="t" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>t</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>. Each person raises <math alttext="5" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>5</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> dollars for each lap run. Write an expression for the rate of change, in dollars per minute, of the total money raised at time <math alttext="t equals 18" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>t</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>18</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> minutes.

(g) Explain why the following could not be a slope field for the differential equation <math alttext="the derivative of y with respect to t, equals negative 0.35 y" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mfrac><mrow><mi>d</mi><mi>y</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>d</mi><mi>t</mi></mrow></mfrac><mo>=</mo><mrow><mo>−</mo><mn>0.35</mn><mi>y</mi></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math>.

topic.text: 4.1: Interpreting the Meaning of the Derivative in Context

skill.text: Skill 1.D: Identify an appropriate mathematical rule or procedure based on the relationship between concepts (e.g., rate of change and accumulation) or processes (e.g., differentiation and its inverse process, anti-differentiation) to solve problems.
